hypothesis_content.title: Negative Macro Catalyst Amplification in Neutral Regime
hypothesis_content.statement: In a NEUTRAL regime (confidence > 55%), a negative macro catalyst (e.g., hawkish central bank signal, geopolitical escalation) will trigger a BTC price decline that is 1.8-2.5x larger than the initial 1-hour move, as measured by the 4-hour close, due to amplified risk-off flows from leveraged long positions.
hypothesis_content.rationale: Neutral regimes often have elevated leverage (longs) due to directional uncertainty. A clear negative catalyst triggers disproportionate liquidations, creating a self-reinforcing downward move. The Japan rate hike news provides a proximate catalyst example.
entry_conditions: Negative macro catalyst identified via news sentiment score < -0.7 (on -1 to 1 scale) within a 1-hour window
BTC 1-hour candle closes down > 2.5% from pre-catalyst level
BTC funding rates positive (> 0.005% per 8h) indicating leveraged longs

exit_conditions.take_profit: Price reaches -4.5% to -6.0% from entry (targeting 1.8-2.5x amplification of initial move)
exit_conditions.stop_loss: Price reclaims the 1-hour pre-catalyst high (catalyst failure)
exit_conditions.time_exit: 24 hours after entry if neither TP nor SL hit

hypothesis_content.falsification_criteria: In NEUTRAL regimes, negative catalysts produce median 4-hour moves less than 1.5x the initial 1-hour move, or more than 30% of such events see rapid reversal within 4 hours.
